PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A MEETING OF EXPLORATION TO THE PIONEER

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2

It is difficult to traverse a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to complete it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use your best judgment in answering these questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, but may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Canadian Pioneers? Have you ever heard of Saskatchewan Archives? If so, what do you know about it?

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of those are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health committees
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A TOOL OF RESEARCH TO THE PERSON INTERESTED IN HISTORY

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so do not worry about leaving blank spaces. Use your best ability to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past That Is," was sent out last fall, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

SASKATCHEWAN IMMIGRANT QUESTIONNAIRE

Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you do not have someone else do the writing at your direction, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: GEORGE H. BIGHAM.
2. Your address: KERREROBERT, SASK.
3. Date: April 14th, 1952.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BOTHWELL, KENT COUNTY, ONTARIO CANADA.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: WALLACE ANDREW BIGHAM farming.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1906.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Detroit, Michigan, USA (from fall of 1904 to February 1906).
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child".
   - It was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - I was working at office work in the city which I have worked all with my brothers and I'm ill me.
   - I didn't have to get outside work and I had no trade and you would have to try my luck on a Homestead.
   - No money to be had.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or Government Information?).

Through friends.
Bigham, George Herbert
Kerrrobert.

PIONEER SURVEY QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: GEORGE H. BIGHAM.
2. Your address: KERRROBERT, SASK.
3. Date: April 14th, 1952.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BOTHWELL, KENT COUNTY, ONTARIO CANADA.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: WALLACE ANDREW BIGHAM.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1906.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Detroit, Michigan, U.S.A. (fall of 1904) to January 1906.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age at that time).
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - I came west because of the opportunity to get a good job and make a living.
   - I would have to try very hard once here.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Through friends
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My friends were not too much in favor of my coming.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

My younger brother and I came together along with several friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by Grand Trunk Railway or Canadian National to Saskatchewan, from there on we walked.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the Bighorn's Hotel in Saskatoon

16. Where did you settle or take up land? About 125 miles south west of Delisle and worked as a farm hand, then after January and worked as a farm hand.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was raised on a farm when I left home until the city.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My friends were not too much in favor of my coming west, but they were capable of making very good decisions.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with others? If so, who?

I traveled by myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by train through railway or bus and then walked to Saskatchewan from there on our way.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the Regina Hotel in Saskatchewan.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? About how far from the city of Regina?

Saskatoon S.W. - 33-33 - 33

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was raised on a farm where I helped out with the work of Detroit and worked as a farm hand. After coming here I worked as a farm hand, then after some weeks I worked as a farm hand again. In the summer of 1906 I worked for Mr. Babler on his farm in Dundasville district of Saskatoon.
and helped move the raft 3 summers on my homestead and the winters in the balloon. Worked for L.H. Stewart who operated a coal and wood business and also stable on the homestead also a short time for the anti-tse tse under Andy Band and from January 15th to April 15th 1910 in the J.F. Carino's store. Also furnishing help along with Maud and Frank. Bob Hargraves and Randy Butler. From then on I managed to make enough off my homestead to carry on without going out working in winter.
and spent most of the next 3 summers on my homestead and the winters in Saskatoon. I worked for J.H. Stewart who operated a coal and wood business and stable on the Crescent also a short time for the Arctic Ice Co under Andy Lund and from January to April 15th 1910 in the J.F. Cairns store, Scott Furnishing Dept along with McLeod, Guy Mack, Bob Hargrove & Randy Burton. From there we managed to make enough off my homestead to carry on without going out working in winter.
